measured_by: five-item willingness ratings for robot household object tasks (cleaning, laundry, watering plants, cooking, handling valuables) on a 7-point Likert scale
justification: “participants were asked to report their degree of willingness to trust the robot to perform five household tasks … composited as a measure of Trust in Care of Objects, α = .87”

measured_by: five-item willingness ratings for robot care of living agents (pets, elderly, teenagers, young children, infants) on a 7-point Likert scale
justification: “to provide care to five different types of living agents … composited as a measure of Trust in Care of Agents, α = .90”

measured_by: seven-item willingness ratings for robot handling sensitive personal data (bank info, passwords, SSN, etc.) on a 7-point Likert scale
justification: “participants were asked to report their willingness to Trust in Care of Information … bank account information, credit and debit card numbers, online passwords, social security numbers, healthcare-related information, passport and/or driver's license information, α = .97”

measured_by: two-item scale: “The robot seems friendly”, “I like this robot” (7-point Likert)
justification: “Participants were also asked to rate their appraisals of the robot's likability ("The robot seems friendly", "I like this robot"; r = .71)”

measured_by: two-item scale: “The robot seems intelligent”, “The robot seems responsible” (7-point Likert)
justification: “appraisals of the robot's … intelligence ("The robot seems intelligent", "The robot seems responsible"; r = .74)”

measured_by: two-item scale: “The robot seems conscious”, “The robot seems alive” (7-point Likert)
justification: “appraisals of … aliveness ("The robot seems conscious", "The robot seems alive"; r = .83)”

measured_by: two-item scale: “The robot seems nurturing”, “The robot seems warm” (7-point Likert)
justification: “we solicited participants' appraisals of the robot's Nurturant qualities (i.e., "The robot seems nurturing", "The robot seems warm", r = .77)”

measured_by: three-item scale: “The robot seems assertive”, “The robot seems confident”, “The robot seems dominant” (7-point Likert)
justification: “an exploratory measure of assertiveness … "The robot seems assertive", "The robot seems confident", "The robot seems dominant", α = .76”

measured_by: three-item sympathy scale after assault vignette: “I would feel sorry for the robot”, “I would feel sympathetic for the robot”, “I would wish for the person to stop hitting the robot” (7-point Likert)
justification: “They were then asked to rate … "I would feel sorry for the robot," "I would feel sympathetic for the robot," "I would wish for the person to stop hitting the robot". The three items (αs > .88)”

measured_by: four-item PAS-HE subscale (e.g., “Automated systems rarely make mistakes”)
justification: “The PAS model … High Expectations in automated systems (PAS-HE; four items, e.g., "Automated systems rarely make mistakes"; αs > .84)”

measured_by: three-item PAS-AN subscale (e.g., “If an automated system makes a mistake, then it is completely useless”)
justification: “All-or-None beliefs … (PAS-AN; three items, e.g., "If an automated system makes a mistake, then it is completely useless"; αs > .75)”

measured_by: difference score from two 10-point items rating capability of men vs. women
justification: “gender bias in appraisals of capability were assessed according to two items ("Please rate your feelings towards men", "Please rate your feelings towards women") … the scores … were then subtracted … to create a bias difference score”

measured_by: five-item ratings of trust in robot to carry clothes, food, computer, money, or a baby (7-point Likert)
justification: “participants were asked to rate their trust in the robot to physically carry their clothes, their food, their computer, their money, or a baby … These measures were dropped in subsequent experiments as evidently redundant”
